paragraphs.title: Getting Started with Spark - Spark Workshop, Code4Lib 2018
paragraphs.text:
%md
Spark Workshop, code4lib 2018
Materials at [github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018](https://github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018)

The following steps should also be available, with other notes, here: [https://github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018/tree/master/worksheets/](https://github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018/tree/master/worksheets) .

msg.data:
Spark Workshop, code4lib 2018
Materials at github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018

The following steps should also be available, with other notes, here: https://github.com/spark4lib/code4lib2018/tree/master/worksheets/ .

paragraphs.title: Introduction
paragraphs.text:
%md
In this session, you will learn Zeppelin, Spark, & Spark SQL basics via primarily the DataFrames API. We are starting with a really simple dataset to focus on the tools. In the next session, we will use an expanded cultural heritage metadata set.

#### Datasets? DataFrames?

A **Dataset** is a distributed collection of data. Dataset provides the benefits of strong typing, ability to use powerful lambda functions with the benefits of (Spark SQL’s) optimized execution engine. A Dataset can be constructed from JVM objects and then manipulated using functional transformations (map, flatMap, filter, etc.). The Dataset API is available in Scala and Java.

A **DataFrame** is a Dataset organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. The DataFrame API is available in Scala, Java, Python, and R. In Scala and Java, a DataFrame is represented by a Dataset of Rows. In the Scala API, DataFrame is simply a type alias of Dataset[Row]. (Note that in Scala type parameters (generics) are enclosed in square brackets.)

[[source](http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.0.0/sql-programming-guide.html#datasets-and-dataframes)]

#### How to run a paragraph

To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook, you can either click the `play` button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or click on the paragraph simply press `Shift + Enter`.

#### What are Zeppelin Interpreters?

In the following paragraphs we are going to execute Spark code, run shell commands to download and move files, run sql queries etc. Each paragraph will start with `%` followed by an interpreter name, e.g. `%spark2` for a Spark 2.x interpreter. Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc.  This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

- `` - the default interpreter is set to be PySpark for our Workshop Docker Container.
- `%spark` - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala
- `%spark.sql` - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)
- `%sh` - Shell interpreter to run shell commands
- `%angular` - Angular interpreter to run Angular and HTML code
- `%md` - Markdown for displaying formatted text, links, and images

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this [link](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.5.6-incubating/manual/interpreters.html).

msg.data:
In this session, you will learn Zeppelin, Spark, & Spark SQL basics via primarily the DataFrames API. We are starting with a really simple dataset to focus on the tools. In the next session, we will use an expanded cultural heritage metadata set.

Datasets? DataFrames?

A Dataset is a distributed collection of data. Dataset provides the benefits of strong typing, ability to use powerful lambda functions with the benefits of (Spark SQL’s) optimized execution engine. A Dataset can be constructed from JVM objects and then manipulated using functional transformations (map, flatMap, filter, etc.). The Dataset API is available in Scala and Java.

A DataFrame is a Dataset organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. The DataFrame API is available in Scala, Java, Python, and R. In Scala and Java, a DataFrame is represented by a Dataset of Rows. In the Scala API, DataFrame is simply a type alias of Dataset[Row]. (Note that in Scala type parameters (generics) are enclosed in square brackets.)

[source]

How to run a paragraph

To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook, you can either click the play button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or click on the paragraph simply press Shift + Enter.

What are Zeppelin Interpreters?

In the following paragraphs we are going to execute Spark code, run shell commands to download and move files, run sql queries etc. Each paragraph will start with % followed by an interpreter name, e.g. %spark2 for a Spark 2.x interpreter. Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc. This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

  • `` - the default interpreter is set to be PySpark for our Workshop Docker Container.
  • %spark - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala
  • %spark.sql - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)
  • %sh - Shell interpreter to run shell commands
  • %angular - Angular interpreter to run Angular and HTML code
  • %md - Markdown for displaying formatted text, links, and images

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this link.

paragraphs.title: Environment Set-up Test
paragraphs.text:
%spark

println("Spark Version: " + sc.version)

val penndata = sc.textFile("penn.csv")
val cmoadata = sc.textFile("cmoa.csv")
println("penn count: " + penndata.count)
println("cmoadata count: " + cmoadata.count)

cmoadata: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[String] = cmoa.csv MapPartitionsRDD[2540] at textFile at <console>:27
penn count: 379317
cmoadata count: 34596

paragraphs.title: Temporary Python Repair of CSV Newlines within PySpark
paragraphs.text:
import csv

# we will see a cleaner way using pyspark to handle this issue later
# though really, use proper quoting with Spark 2.2.x & multifile=True

with open('code4lib2018/sample-data/small-sample.csv') as fh:
    test = csv.reader(fh)
    with open('code4lib2018/sample-data/small-sample-stripped.csv', 'w') as fout:
        test_write = csv.writer(fout, quoting=csv.QUOTE_ALL)
        for row in test:
            new_row = [val.replace("\r\n", "") for val in row]
            test_write.writerow(new_row)

paragraphs.title: Check that Our Temporary Repair Worked for our CSV
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cat 'code4lib2018/sample-data/small-sample-stripped.csv'

paragraphs.title: Revisit our CSV as a Dataframe & It's Inferred Schema
paragraphs.text: spark.read.csv("code4lib2018/sample-data/small-sample-stripped.csv", header=True, inferSchema=True).printSchema()

msg.data:
root
 |-- Name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Institution Type: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Format: string (nullable = true)
 |-- URL: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Description: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Informal Score: integer (nullable = true)

paragraphs.title: Create Our Own Schema & Read the CSV into a Dataframe Instance with our Schema
paragraphs.text:
from pyspark.sql.types import *

customSchema = StructType([
  StructField("Name", StringType(), True),
  StructField("Institution Type", StringType(), True),
  StructField("Format", StringType(), True),
  StructField("URL", StringType(), True),
  StructField("Description", StringType(), True),
  StructField("Informal Score", DecimalType(), True)])

sampleDf = spark.read.csv("code4lib2018/sample-data/small-sample-stripped.csv", header=True, schema=customSchema)
sampleDf.show()

%md
### Stopping Point: Have you been able to walk through and load your CSV?

msg.data: Stopping Point: Have you been able to walk through and load your CSV?

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Part 2: Simple Analysis of our Dataset via Dataframe API

msg.data: Part 2: Simple Analysis of our Dataset via Dataframe API

paragraphs.title: Return First n Rows in your Dataframe ( .head(n) )
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.head(2)

msg.data: [Row(Name=u'CMOA', Institution Type=u'Museum', Format=u'JSON, CSV', URL=u'https://github.com/cmoa/collection', Description=None, Informal Score=Decimal('10')), Row(Name=u'Penn Museum', Institution Type=u'Museum', Format=u'JSON, CSV, XML', URL=u'https://www.penn.museum/collections/data.php', Description=u'JSON is poorly structured', Informal Score=Decimal('7'))]

paragraphs.title: Show Columns ( .columns() ) & Number of Columns ( .len() ) in your Dataframe
paragraphs.text:
print(sampleDf.columns)
print(len(sampleDf.columns))

msg.data:
['Name', 'Institution Type', 'Format', 'URL', 'Description', 'Informal Score']
6

paragraphs.title: Show Specific Columns ( .select() )
paragraphs.text:
sampleDf.select("Name").show()
sampleDf.select("Name", "Informal Score").show()

paragraphs.title: Selecting Columns ( .select() ) versus Apply Filters ( .filter() )
paragraphs.text:
scoresBooleanDf = sampleDf.select('Name', 'URL', sampleDf['Informal Score'] > 5)
scoresBooleanDf.show()

highScoresDf = sampleDf.filter(sampleDf['Informal Score'] > 5)
highScoresDf.select('Name', 'URL', 'Informal Score').show()

paragraphs.title: How Many Rows? ( .count() )
paragraphs.text:
numSampleDf = sampleDf.count()
numHighScoresDf = highScoresDf.count()

print("Percentage of Datasets with a Score at or above 5: " + str(float(numHighScoresDf)/float(numSampleDf)*100) + "%")

msg.data: Percentage of Datasets with a Score at or above 5: 50.0%

paragraphs.title: Show First n Rows of Dataframe in Show View ( .show(n) )
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.show(2,truncate=True)

paragraphs.title: Show Stats Summary of your Dataframe ( .describe() )
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.describe().show()

paragraphs.title: Show Stats Summary of a Specific Column ( .describe(colName) , DecimalType)
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.describe('Informal Score').show()

paragraphs.title: Show Stats Summary of a Specific Column ( .describe(colName) , StringType)
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.describe('URL').show()

%md
### Stopping Point: Have you been able to walk through reviewing some Rows & Columns?

msg.data: Stopping Point: Have you been able to walk through reviewing some Rows & Columns?

paragraphs.title: Your Working Space: Analysis of Data I
Order Dataframe Views by a Column ( .orderBy(colName) | .orderBy(colName).desc() )
paragraphs.text:
sampleDf.orderBy("Informal Score").show()
sampleDf.orderBy(sampleDf["Informal Score"].desc()).show()

paragraphs.title: Group Values by a Column ( .groupBy(colName) )
paragraphs.text:
URLGroupDf = sampleDf.groupBy("Format").count()

URLGroupDf.show()
URLGroupDf.printSchema()

msg.data:
+--------------+-----+
|        Format|count|
+--------------+-----+
|           CSV|    1|
|           XML|    1|
|     JSON, CSV|    1|
|JSON, CSV, XML|    1|
|       RDF/XML|    1|
|  CSV,JSON,XML|    1|
+--------------+-----+

root
 |-- Format: string (nullable = true)
 |-- count: long (nullable = false)

paragraphs.title: Group Values by a Column then Compute an Aggregation ( .agg(expr) )
paragraphs.text:
# Note, this is setting us up for Splitting Values later on

formatGroupDf = sampleDf.groupBy("Format").agg({"Informal Score": 'mean'})
formatGroupDf.show()
formatGroupDf.printSchema()

paragraphs.title: Show & Count Distinct Values in a Selected Column ( .distinct() )
paragraphs.text:
# Note, this is also setting us up for Splitting Values later on

distinctFormatDf = sampleDf.select("Format").distinct()
distinctFormatDf.show()
distinctFormatDf.count()

paragraphs.title: Use Aggregations ( .agg() ) & Sql Functions for Number of Distinct Values in Format ( countDistinct(colName) )
paragraphs.text:
from pyspark.sql.functions import countDistinct

countDistinctDF = sampleDf.select("Name", "Institution Type", "Format").groupBy("Institution Type").agg(countDistinct("Format"))
countDistinctDF.show()

%md
### Stopping Point: Have you been able to group, order, get distinct values by column(s)?

msg.data: Stopping Point: Have you been able to group, order, get distinct values by column(s)?

paragraphs.title: Your Working Space: Analysis of Data II

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Part 3: Creating New Dataframes to Expand or Rework our Original Dataset

msg.data: Part 3: Creating New Dataframes to Expand or Rework our Original Dataset

paragraphs.title: Create a Dataframe of DeDuplicated Values ( .dropDuplicates() )
paragraphs.text:
scoresDf = sampleDf.select('Informal Score').dropDuplicates()
scoresDf.show()

paragraphs.title: Create a Dataframe with Null Values Dropped ( .dropna() ) or Null Values Filled ( .fillna(fillerVal) )
paragraphs.text:
noNullDf = sampleDf.select('Name', 'URL').dropna()
noNullDf.show()

nonNullDf = sampleDf.select('Name', 'URL').fillna('No URL')
nonNullDf.show()

paragraphs.title: Create Dataframe where URL is Non Null ( col.isNull() && .filter() )
paragraphs.text:
filterNonNullDF = sampleDf.filter(sampleDf.URL.isNull()).sort("Name")
filterNonNullDF.show()

%md
### Stopping Point: Create some Derivative Dataframes

msg.data: Stopping Point: Create some Derivative Dataframes

paragraphs.title: Your Working Space: Deriving Data I
Create a new DataFrame with 'Format Array' column ( .withColumn(colName, colValue) ) of Split Values ( split(col, delimiter) )
paragraphs.text:
from pyspark.sql.functions import split

sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn("Format Array", split(sampleDf.Format, ","))
sampleDf.show()
sampleDf.printSchema()

paragraphs.title: Use pyspark.sql.functions Explode ( explode(col) ) & Split ( .split(colName, delimiter) ) to Create a Row for each unique Format Value
paragraphs.text:
from pyspark.sql.functions import explode

sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn("Format", explode(split("Format", ",")))
sampleDf.show()

paragraphs.title: Create New Columns ( withColumn(colName, colValue) ) with Boolean if Format Type Present ( .like(Regex) )
paragraphs.text:
sampleDf.select("Format").distinct().show()
sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn('CSV', sampleDf.Format.like("%CSV%"))
sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn('XML', sampleDf.Format.like("%XML%"))
sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn('RDF', sampleDf.Format.like("%RDF%"))
sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn('JSON', sampleDf.Format.like("%JSON%"))
sampleDf.show()

|                DPLA|     Aggregator |    XML|               dp.la|                null|           100|  [CSV, JSON, XML]|false| true|false|false|
+--------------------+----------------+-------+--------------------+--------------------+--------------+------------------+-----+-----+-----+-----+

paragraphs.title: Transform our Dataframe to RDD ( .rdd ) & Map a function ( .map(lambda) )
paragraphs.text:
sampleRdd = sampleDf.select("Format").rdd.map(lambda x: x[0].split(","))
sampleRdd.take(5)

msg.data: [[u'JSON'], [u' CSV'], [u'JSON'], [u' CSV'], [u' XML']]

paragraphs.title: Drop the Previous Format Array Column
paragraphs.text:
sampleDf = sampleDf.drop('Format Array')
sampleDf.show()

|                CMOA|          Museum|   JSON|https://github.co...|                null|            10|false|false|false| true|
|                CMOA|          Museum|    CSV|https://github.co...|                null|            10| true|false|false|false|
|         Penn Museum|          Museum|   JSON|https://www.penn....|JSON is poorly st...|             7|false|false|false| true|
|         Penn Museum|          Museum|    CSV|https://www.penn....|JSON is poorly st...|             7| true|false|false|false|
|         Penn Museum|          Museum|    XML|https://www.penn....|JSON is poorly st...|             7|false| true|false|false|
|          Met Museum|          Museum|    CSV|                null|            ¯_(ツ)_/¯|             3| true|false|false|false|

paragraphs.title: Check our Distinct Format Values Now
paragraphs.text: sampleDf.select("Format").distinct().show()

paragraphs.title: Remove Whitespace around Format using Regex ( reqexp_replace(colName, regex to replace, new value) )
paragraphs.text:
from pyspark.sql.functions import regexp_replace

sampleDf = sampleDf.withColumn("Format", regexp_replace(sampleDf.Format, "\s+", ""))
sampleDf.select("Format").distinct().show()

paragraphs.title: Create Dataframe where Format is CSV ( .where(conditional) )
paragraphs.text:
CSVsampleDf = sampleDf.where((sampleDf.Format == "CSV"))
CSVsampleDf.show()

# Part 4: Using SQL to Analyze our Dataset

msg.data: Part 4: Using SQL to Analyze our Dataset

paragraphs.title: Introduction to SQL Queries
paragraphs.text:
%md
To have a more dynamic experience, let’s create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to execute SQL queries against it.

Note that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive. [Here](http://cse.unl.edu/~sscott/ShowFiles/SQL/CheatSheet/SQLCheatSheet.html) is a SQL Cheatsheet in case you need it.

msg.data:
To have a more dynamic experience, let’s create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to execute SQL queries against it.

Note that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive. Here is a SQL Cheatsheet in case you need it.

paragraphs.title: Creating a Temporary SQL View from our Sample Dataframe & Running a Simple SQL Query
paragraphs.text:
# Convert SampleDF DataFrame to a temporary view
sampleDf.createOrReplaceTempView("sampleDataView")

sparkQuery = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM sampleDataView LIMIT 20")
sparkQuery.collect()

msg.data: [Row(Name=u'CMOA', Institution Type=u'Museum', Format=u'JSON, CSV', URL=u'https://github.com/cmoa/collection', Description=None, Informal Score=Decimal('10')), Row(Name=u'Penn Museum', Institution Type=u'Museum', Format=u'JSON, CSV, XML', URL=u'https://www.penn.museum/collections/data.php', Description=u'JSON is poorly structured', Informal Score=Decimal('7')), Row(Name=u'Met Museum', Institution Type=u'Museum', Format=u'CSV', URL=None, Description=u'\xaf_(\u30c4)_/\xaf', Informal Score=Decimal('3')), Row(Name=u'DigitalNZ Te Puna Web Directory', Institution Type=u'Library', Format=u'XML', URL=u'https://natlib.govt.nz/files/data/tepunawebdirectory.xml', Description=u'MARC XML', Informal Score=Decimal('3')), Row(Name=u'Canadian Subject Headings', Institution Type=u'Library', Format=u'RDF/XML', URL=u'http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/obj/900/f11/040004/csh.rdf', Description=u'Ugh, rdf', Informal Score=Decimal('4')), Row(Name=u'DPLA', Institution Type=u'Aggregator ', Format=u'CSV,JSON,XML', URL=u'dp.la', Description=None, Informal Score=Decimal('100'))]

paragraphs.title: Querying our Temporary View for Number of Distinct Formats per Institution Type
paragraphs.text:
sparkQuery = spark.sql("""SELECT `Institution Type`, COUNT(DISTINCT(Format)) AS NumFormats FROM sampleDataView GROUP BY `Institution Type`""")
sparkQuery.collect()
for n in sparkQuery.collect():
    n

msg.data:
Row(Institution Type=u'Library', NumFormats=2)
Row(Institution Type=u'Aggregator ', NumFormats=1)
Row(Institution Type=u'Museum', NumFormats=3)

paragraphs.text:
%sql 
SELECT `Institution Type`, COUNT(DISTINCT(Format)) AS NumFormats
FROM sampleDataView
GROUP BY `Institution Type`

msg.data:
Institution Type	NumFormats
Library	2
Aggregator 	1
Museum	3
